1.1.Principle: Text Alternatives: Provide text alternatives for any non-text content so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as large print, Braille, speech, symbols or simpler language.

1.2.Principle: Time-based Media: Provide alternatives for time-based media.

1.3.Principle: Adaptable: Create content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure.

1.4.Principle: Distinguishable: Make it easier for users to see and hear content including separating foreground from background.

2.1.Principle: Keyboard Accessible: Make all functionality available from a keyboard.

2.2.Principle: Enough Time: Provide users enough time to read and use content.

2.3.Principle: Seizures: Do not design content in a way that is known to cause seizures.

2.4.Principle: Navigable: Provide ways to help users navigate, find content, and determine where they are.

2.5.Principle: Input Modalities: Make it easier for users to operate functionality through various inputs beyond the keyboard.

3.1.Principle: Readable: Make text content readable and understandable.

3.2.Principle: Predictable: Make Web pages appear and operate in predictable ways.

3.3.Principle: Input Assistance: Help users avoid and correct mistakes.

4.1.Principle: Compatible: Maximize compatibility with current & future user agents, including assistive technologies
